message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Copper-containing intra-uterine device is the most effective emergency contraceptive method and is suitable for the patient who does not want her parents to be informed of the visit. Ulipristal acetate, combined oral contraceptive, and progestin-containing intra-uterine device are also effective but may require parental consent for minors.

We refer to the website of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists for guidance. The most appropriate step is to insert a copper-containing intrauterine device (IUD) within 5 days of unprotected sex. The IUD is effective in preventing pregnancy and can be left in place for long-term contraception. Ulipristal acetate and combined oral contraceptives can also be used as emergency contraception, but they are less effective than the IUD. Inserting a progestin-containing IUD could provide long-term contraception, but it is not as effective as the copper-containing IUD for emergency contraception. Keeping the patient's confidentiality is important and is a part of basic patient rights.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient had unprotected sexual intercourse and does not wish for her parents to know implies that emergency contraception is needed. Copper-containing intra-uterine devices (IUDs) have high efficacy and can be used up to 5 days after unprotected intercourse. Ulipristal acetate can also be used but is less effective than copper-containing IUDs. Progestin-containing IUDs and combined oral contraceptives are not effective as emergency contraception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient does not wish to become pregnant, emergency contraception is necessary. Among the options, the most effective method is a copper-containing intrauterine device (IUD).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents within 24 hours of unprotected intercourse, and the most effective method of emergency contraception in this scenario is a copper-containing intra-uterine device (IUD). It can be inserted up to 5 days after unprotected intercourse and provides long-term contraception if desired. Ulipristal acetate and combined oral contraceptives can also be used as emergency contraception, but they are less effective than a copper-containing IUD. Inserting a progestin-containing IUD is not indicated for emergency contraception. Confidentiality concerning the patient's visit and medical care is also important to respect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In this scenario, the patient had unprotected intercourse and wishes to prevent pregnancy. The most appropriate step would be to insert a copper-containing intra-uterine device (IUD), which provides effective contraception for up to 10 years and can be inserted up to 5 days after unprotected intercourse. Ulipristal acetate can also be used as emergency contraception but should be taken within 120 hours of unprotected intercourse. Progestin-containing IUD and combined oral contraceptives can also be used for contraception but are not as effective for emergency contraception. It is important to respect the patient's wishes regarding confidentiality and inform her of any potential risks or side effects of the chosen method.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient had unprotected sex and does not wish to become pregnant. The most appropriate step in management is to use emergency contraception. Copper-containing intra-uterine devices can be used up to 5 days after unprotected intercourse and are more effective than other forms of emergency contraception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient had unprotected intercourse within 120 hours of presentation and wants to avoid pregnancy until after college, the most appropriate management option is to insert a copper-containing intrauterine device. The other options are also used for emergency contraception but they are less effective than the copper-containing intrauterine device in preventing pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most appropriate step in management for this patient is to insert a copper-containing intra-uterine device (IUD). Ulipristal acetate and combined oral contraceptives are also options, but they require a prescription and may have side effects. Insertion of a progestin-containing IUD is an option, but the copper-containing IUD has a higher efficacy rate for emergency contraception. The patient’s request for confidentiality should be respected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient had unprotected sexual intercourse and wants to prevent pregnancy without informing her parents. Copper-containing intrauterine devices are highly effective in preventing pregnancy and can be inserted up to 5 days after unprotected intercourse. Ulipristal acetate, a progestin-containing intrauterine device, and combined oral contraceptives are also options for emergency contraception but may require a prescription and may not be as effective as a copper-containing intrauterine device.
